Should the periodic query also happen at standby state?

> Should the periodic query also happen at standby state?

Yes it will happen. 
Switch Ethernet12 to `standby` on UT0:
```
Nov  1 18:16:06.911026 svcstr-7050-acs-1 WARNING mux#linkmgrd: MuxManager.cpp:207 updateMuxPortConfig: Ethernet12: Mux port config: standby
Nov  1 18:16:06.911230 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE swss#orchagent: :- handleMuxCfg: Ethernet12: 192.168.0.7 was added to ignored neighbor list
Nov  1 18:16:06.911316 svcstr-7050-acs-1 WARNING mux#linkmgrd: link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachineActiveActive.cpp:933 switchMuxState: Ethernet12: Switching MUX state to 'Standby'
Nov  1 18:16:06.911316 svcstr-7050-acs-1 WARNING mux#linkmgrd: link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachineActiveActive.cpp:249 handleMuxConfigNotification: Ethernet12: (P: Active, M: Active, L: Up) -> (P: Active, M: Standby, L: Up)
```
Periodical query returns `standby` every 10s: 
```
Nov  1 18:16:14.990922 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE pmon#ycable[35]: calling RPC for getting forwarding state port = Ethernet12 portid 1 peer portid 0 read_side 1
Nov  1 18:16:14.993019 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE pmon#ycable[35]: forwarding state RPC received response port = Ethernet12 portids [0, 1] read_side 1
Nov  1 18:16:14.993275 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE pmon#ycable[35]: forwarding state RPC received response port = Ethernet12 state values = [True, False] read_side 1
Nov  1 18:16:14.993669 svcstr-7050-acs-1 WARNING mux#linkmgrd: link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachineActiveActive.cpp:263 handleProbeMuxStateNotification: Ethernet12: app db mux state: Standby
Nov  1 18:16:14.993885 svcstr-7050-acs-1 WARNING mux#linkmgrd: link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachineActiveActive.cpp:329 handlePeerMuxStateNotification: Ethernet12: state db mux state: Active
Nov  1 18:16:24.959378 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE pmon#ycable[35]: calling RPC for getting forwarding state port = Ethernet12 portid 1 peer portid 0 read_side 1
Nov  1 18:16:24.961225 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE pmon#ycable[35]: forwarding state RPC received response port = Ethernet12 portids [0, 1] read_side 1
Nov  1 18:16:24.961307 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE pmon#ycable[35]: forwarding state RPC received response port = Ethernet12 state values = [True, False] read_side 1
Nov  1 18:16:24.961971 svcstr-7050-acs-1 WARNING mux#linkmgrd: link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachineActiveActive.cpp:263 handleProbeMuxStateNotification: Ethernet12: app db mux state: Standby
Nov  1 18:16:24.961971 svcstr-7050-acs-1 WARNING mux#linkmgrd: link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachineActiveActive.cpp:329 handlePeerMuxStateNotification: Ethernet12: state db mux state: Active
Nov  1 18:16:34.948345 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE pmon#ycable[35]: calling RPC for getting forwarding state port = Ethernet12 portid 1 peer portid 0 read_side 1
Nov  1 18:16:34.950705 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE pmon#ycable[35]: forwarding state RPC received response port = Ethernet12 portids [0, 1] read_side 1
Nov  1 18:16:34.950801 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE pmon#ycable[35]: forwarding state RPC received response port = Ethernet12 state values = [True, False] read_side 1
Nov  1 18:16:34.951288 svcstr-7050-acs-1 WARNING mux#linkmgrd: link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachineActiveActive.cpp:263 handleProbeMuxStateNotification: Ethernet12: app db mux state: Standby
Nov  1 18:16:34.951288 svcstr-7050-acs-1 WARNING mux#linkmgrd: link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachineActiveActive.cpp:329 handlePeerMuxStateNotification: Ethernet12: state db mux state: Active
```

Force T0 to set peer Ethernet12 to `active`
```
admin@svcstr-7050-acs-2:~$ redis-cli -n 0 
127.0.0.1:6379> hset "HW_FORWARDING_STATE_PEER:Ethernet12" state active
(integer) 0
127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall HW_FORWARDING_STATE_PEER:Ethernet12
1) "state"
2) "active"
```

UT0 detected difference and resync to `standby`: 
```
Nov  1 18:28:44.972179 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE pmon#ycable[35]: calling RPC for getting forwarding state port = Ethernet12 portid 1 peer portid 0 read_side 1
Nov  1 18:28:44.973965 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE pmon#ycable[35]: forwarding state RPC received response port = Ethernet12 portids [0, 1] read_side 1
Nov  1 18:28:44.973965 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE pmon#ycable[35]: forwarding state RPC received response port = Ethernet12 state values = [True, True] read_side 1
Nov  1 18:28:44.974716 svcstr-7050-acs-1 WARNING mux#linkmgrd: link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachineActiveActive.cpp:263 handleProbeMuxStateNotification: Ethernet12: app db mux state: Active
Nov  1 18:28:44.974716 svcstr-7050-acs-1 WARNING mux#linkmgrd: link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachineActiveActive.cpp:329 handlePeerMuxStateNotification: Ethernet12: state db mux state: Active
Nov  1 18:28:44.974716 svcstr-7050-acs-1 WARNING mux#linkmgrd: link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachineActiveActive.cpp:512 handleStateChange: Ethernet12: Received mux state event, new state: Active
Nov  1 18:28:44.974752 svcstr-7050-acs-1 WARNING mux#linkmgrd: link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachineActiveActive.cpp:933 switchMuxState: Ethernet12: Switching MUX state to 'Standby'
Nov  1 18:28:44.975751 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE swss#orchagent: :- setState: [Ethernet12] Set MUX state from standby to standby
Nov  1 18:28:44.998835 svcstr-7050-acs-1 NOTICE pmon#ycable[35]: calling RPC for hw mux_cable set state ispeer = False port Ethernet12 portid 1 read_side 1 state requested standby
```

```

[2022-10-21 02:31:43.374361] [debug] link_prober/ActiveState.cpp:77 handleEvent: Ethernet12
[2022-10-21 02:31:43.374525] [debug] link_prober/ActiveState.cpp:117 resetState: Ethernet12
[2022-10-21 02:31:43.374611] [debug] link_prober/PeerActiveState.cpp:46 handleEvent: Ethernet12
```

With this PR:
```
[2022-10-21 02:34:00.369992] [debug] link_prober/LinkProber.cpp:176 startProbing: Ethernet12
[2022-10-21 02:34:00.370064] [debug] link_prober/LinkProber.cpp:590 startTimer: Ethernet12
[2022-10-21 02:34:00.370134] [debug] link_prober/LinkProber.cpp:935 getProbingInterval: Ethernet12
[2022-10-21 02:34:00.370170] [debug] link_prober/LinkProber.cpp:379 handleRecv: Ethernet12
[2022-10-21 02:34:00.373280] [debug] link_prober/LinkProber.cpp:379 handleRecv: Ethernet12
[2022-10-21 02:34:00.373330] [debug] link_prober/ActiveState.cpp:77 handleEvent: Ethernet12
[2022-10-21 02:34:00.373359] [debug] link_prober/ActiveState.cpp:117 resetState: Ethernet12
[2022-10-21 02:34:00.406605] [debug] link_prober/LinkProber.cpp:379 handleRecv: Ethernet12
[2022-10-21 02:34:00.406648] [debug] link_prober/PeerActiveState.cpp:46 handleEvent: Ethernet12
[2022-10-21 02:34:00.406676] [debug] link_prober/PeerActiveState.cpp:83 resetState: Ethernet12
```
Why do we need to switch to active? Shouldn't the gRPC module report server status?

> Why do we need to switch to active? Shouldn't the gRPC module report server status?

Hi @yxieca - sorry this is introduced by my recent PR. 

Yes gRPC reports the server status, and it falls under one of our "no-op" scenarios (LinkProber == active && Link == up && ServerState == active), but the thing is the local STATE DB entry didn't get updated, hence causing assertion failure in tests.

> Why the probe worked and the toggle failed? Could you please add more details?

We don't know that yet. And I see it only happens with toggling to standby. Will work with Vaibhav to figure out why, this PR is to mitigate.
How to delete the flaky_tests branch?
@zjswhhh do we also need this change in 202012?

> @zjswhhh do we also need this change in 202012?

Yes we do, just added the tag.
@maipbui are you able to create an unit test for this change?

> @maipbui are you able to create an unit test for this change?

@yxieca, sure, working on it

> How about retrying the timeout for a certain amout of times instead of removing all of them?

Checked with Vaibhav offline, the turnaround of gRPC requests should be 5~10ms, our first timeout is 300ms already. Besides, this timeout doesn't do anything except adding one more log, right?

Is max backoff of 128 enough? 128 is 12.8 seconds?

> Is max backoff of 128 enough? 128 is 12.8 seconds?

The maximum interval will be 128* 3*100ms =  38.4 seconds.

https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-linkmgrd/commit/faceb93c1953321580771596be70765b131b03f7
Could you elaborate on why posting mux metrics run after setting mux state is problematic?

> Could you elaborate on why posting mux metrics run after setting mux state is problematic?

When posting a "SwitchStart" event, linkmgrd will clean the whole mux metrics. And if orchagent reacts on "set mux state" before that, the `orch_switch_<active/standby>_start` timestamp will be removed.

Nikola observed this issue a lot in pilot cluster: 
```
24495 PORT        EVENT                          TIME
24496 ----------  -----------------------------  ---------------------------
 
24497 Ethernet52  linkmgrd_switch_standby_start  2022-Jul-25 09:53:29.214514
 
24498 Ethernet52  orch_switch_standby_end        2022-Jul-25 09:53:29.238199
 
24499 Ethernet52  xcvrd_switch_standby_start     2022-Jul-25 09:53:29.251985
 
24500 Ethernet52  xcvrd_switch_standby_end       2022-Jul-25 09:53:29.256608
 
24501 Ethernet52  linkmgrd_switch_standby_end    2022-Jul-25 09:53:29.259217
```

Why do we want to enable passing extra include?

> Why do we want to enable passing extra include?

Because for lgtm, the `swss-common` will not be installed into the system default path. So it will be nice to enable `make` to accept extra includes.

@zjswhhh can you assess how often do these events come up?

When xcvrd is healthy?
When xcvrd is unhealthy?
When xcvrd is healthy but the cable is not healthy?

> @zjswhhh can you assess how often do these events come up?
> 
> When xcvrd is healthy? When xcvrd is unhealthy? When xcvrd is healthy but the cable is not healthy?

Mux probing events come up when there is state inconsistency, config mode change to auto, default route state change to "ok" etc. 

When cable is unhealthy, there will be a mux probing every (300*backoff_factor) ms. backoff_factor increases exponentially for each probe, and the maximum is 8, so eventually the probing interval will be 2.4 s if cable remains bad. 

xcvrd's health is irrelevant to mux probing frequency, it's just linkmgrd won't get probing response. But we do log every 2.4s in warning level today if xcvrd crashes in a middle of switch or probing: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-linkmgrd/blob/ef1f5ebc9a64207e622da1fb11eb78e6d95e7f45/src/link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachine.cpp#L957-L986

> > @zjswhhh can you assess how often do these events come up?
> > When xcvrd is healthy? When xcvrd is unhealthy? When xcvrd is healthy but the cable is not healthy?
> 
> Mux probing events come up when there is state inconsistency, config mode change to auto, default route state change to "ok" etc.
> 
> When cable is unhealthy, there will be a mux probing every (300*backoff_factor) ms. backoff_factor increases exponentially for each probe, and the maximum is 8, so eventually the probing interval will be 2.4 s if cable remains bad.
> 
> xcvrd's health is irrelevant to mux probing frequency, it's just linkmgrd won't get probing response. But we do log every 2.4s in warning level today if xcvrd crashes in a middle of switch or probing:
> 
> https://github.com/Azure/sonic-linkmgrd/blob/ef1f5ebc9a64207e622da1fb11eb78e6d95e7f45/src/link_manager/LinkManagerStateMachine.cpp#L957-L986
So the event rate would be every 2.4 seconds, n (number of ports) events until the cable is healthy. This is quite chatty.

> So the event rate would be every 2.4 seconds, n (number of ports) events until the cable is healthy. This is quite chatty.

Hi @yxieca  I have the maximum backoff factor updated to 32 in PR #22 https://github.com/Azure/sonic-linkmgrd/pull/22/commits/e6d49790b6dfb41fe6aaf0cf5d2fbcb1e80d5020

The event rate will be every 9.6 seconds if the cable remains unhealthy.
Hi @vdahiya12 - could you please review this PR when you get a chance? Thanks!
Lets also test the changes in the lab by bringing the link down on the peer.

> Lets also test the changes in the lab by bringing the link down on the peer.

I tested on virtual testbeds by manually changing the link_status_peer value in state db. Do you mean the physical testbed or?
Conducted tests on virtual testbeds with y_cable simulator reporting peer link state as down, it worked as expected. @vdahiya12

> Do we need a method to reset the packet loss ratio other than restarting the linkmgrd?

Good question. I think we do? Once the ping is back working, we can simply reset so that the ratio number is more meaningful.

boost::asio::ip::make_address is unable to parse "::/0" and "0.0.0.0/0", and considering the key will always be these two strings, I updated the code and removed make_address(). Changes have been tested on virtual dual testbeds and worked as expected. 

@prsunny could you review again? Thanks!
